title: Hedge-Fund Star Robbins Stumbles
summary: The largest fund run by his Glenview Capital Management lost about 16.2% in 2018, according to a person familiar with the matter. Hedge-fund billionaire Larry Robbins earned renown with successful bets on President Obama's health-care overhaul. Those wagers cost him in 2018.

title: Issues That Will Drive Debate in the New Congress
summary: Some action is likely in several areas even with divided government. With a divided Congress and a widening partisan gap among voters, impasses like the partial government shutdown over funding for a border wall promise to dominate policy making for the next two years. But there are some areas where action is likely. Here are six issues to watch:

title: Dollar Slides After Powell's Rate Remarks
summary: The Fed chairman said the central bank wasn't on a preset path to push its benchmark rate higher. The dollar reversed earlier gains Friday, after dovish comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell undercut expectations for how aggressively the central bank will tighten monetary policy this year.

title: Marriott Says Hackers Swiped Millions of Passport Numbers
summary: Hotel chain says fewer total customers were affected than initially feared but analysts warn data could be intelligence trove. Marriott International Inc. said fewer customers were affected in a massive data breach than initially feared but confirmed that hackers had compromised the passport numbers of millions of people in what security analysts have described as a potential foreign-intelligence gold mine.

title: The Lessons of 'Dieselgate'
summary: Insane amounts of political capital were spent trying to wring meaningless CO2 reductions from cars.. Angela Merkel had a bad 2018. Outsiders heard the word "migrants" during her party's many electoral defeats. But a more urgent concern for millions of German voters was the fate of diesel cars they bought because they were told it was good for climate change.

title: Tax-Season Plan for Shutdown Coming Soon, Treasury Says
summary: Administration hasn't yet said when tax-filing season will start or whether it will change guidance on refunds. WASHINGTON-The Treasury Department said Friday the government will update its plan for income-tax filing during a government shutdown "in the coming days," but didn't specify when the Internal Revenue Service would begin accepting 2018 tax returns or whether it was seeking a legal way to issue tax refunds.

title: New House Committee Chiefs Take Their Chairs
summary: The Democrats who will set the agenda on key panels, and what policy changes to expect from them. With control of the House of Representatives, Democrats take over the chairman's seat in the chamber's committees. Here are the men and women who will be setting the agenda for key panels, and what policy changes to expect from them.

title: U.S. Stocks Surge on Powell Remarks, Jobs Report
summary: Dow jumps nearly 750 points as better-than-expected hiring suggests a healthy labor market. U.S. stocks bounced back from their worst two-day start to a year since 2000, soaring Friday after fresh signs of economic strength eased fears that slowing growth around the world could drag on the U.S. expansion.

title: Democratic Leaders Try to Quell Fresh Talk of Impeachment Push
summary: Remarks by freshman congresswoman set off new round of debate in party. WASHINGTON-Democratic leaders sought to tamp down calls for impeachment proceedings against President Trump, saying they are premature and risky, after video of a freshman congresswoman's salty remarks about removing him from office reignited the debate within the party.

title: Cuomo Names Chief of Staff to Lead New York Financial Regulator
summary: Linda Lacewell has served Gov. Cuomo since he was attorney general. Linda Lacewell, a former federal prosecutor who has worked for Gov. Andrew Cuomo since he became attorney general in 2007, was nominated to lead the New York Department of Financial Services, the governor said Friday.

title: Supreme Court Again to Consider Partisan Gerrymandering
summary: High court will hear cases from North Carolina, Maryland after disposing of two other cases last term on procedural grounds. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court will try again to tackle the thorny issue of political gerrymandering, announcing Friday that it will hear cases from North Carolina and Maryland to decide whether there are constitutional limits to how far lawmakers can go in drawing electoral districts to maximize their partisan advantage.

title: U.S. Adds 312,000 Jobs in December as Wages Jump
summary: Employers added 312,000 jobs last month and 2.64 million in 2018, the best year since 2015. WASHINGTON-U. S. employers added jobs at a robust pace in December, and wages posted their biggest full-year gain in a decade, providing a strong counterpoint to Wall Street worries that tariffs and rising interest rates are holding back the economy.

title: Stock-Market Standoff: Apple Warning vs. the Jobs Report
summary: To navigate market upheaval, investors must stick to a plan rather than react to wild gyrations and scary headlines. Friday's blowout jobs report propelled stock indexes into positive territory in a still-very-young 2019 following their worst start to a year in decades. Is it a sign the worst is over or another head fake in what may soon turn into the century's third bear market?

title: Trump Gossip Can't Overshadow His Triumphs
summary: Report on the president's policy failures and accomplishments. That is what matters most.. Peggy Noonan asks "Trump insiders" to speak candidly about how the administration conducts the people's business ("Trump Insiders, Come Out of the Shadows," Declarations, Dec. 29). Two years are indeed enough time to evaluate the conduct of our government-including the duplicity in Congress and the vigilante style of the Justice Department and the IRS. Yet Ms. Noonan focuses her ire on President Trump while overlooking these and other malefactors.

title: Fed-Up Teachers Take Their Chances Elsewhere
summary: A higher turnover rate among teachers will likely continue to increase if wages aren't consistent with the higher cost of living.. I am one of those teachers who chose to retire this year before qualifying for my full pension ("Teachers Are Leaving Their Jobs at Record Rates," U.S. News, Dec. 29). I can't speak to other states, but Texas is currently spending 6.3% less per student, in constant dollars, than it was spending eight years ago. Sixty percent of public-school students in Texas qualify for free or reduced lunch. What this budget shortfall means is that teachers are expected to teach more students with fewer resources and less support. The school day never allows for time to grade; that is done outside school hours. Your readers complain that teachers get three months of vacation each year, but it's not a vacation: it's mandatory unpaid leave.

title: Solace Comes When Life Is What We Remember
summary: Never met a parent or grandparent who regretted the birth of his or her lost child.. As someone who has lost a daughter to suicide and has also lost another daughter and a grandson to medical conditions, I really appreciate and agree with Gayle Somers's op-ed "Life Is Worth Living, Even if It Is Painful and Short" (Dec. 22). My first daughter died at 30 after struggling with substance abuse for 16 years.

title: Shame On Investors Who Let Tweets Fool Them Twice
summary: Eager to deliver good news, Mr. Trump consistently overpromises.. Regarding Martin Feldstein's op-ed "Tariffs Should Target Chinese Lawlessness, Not the Trade Deficit" (Dec. 28): I can't believe the way the market jumps every time President Trump tweets about trade talks. Eager to deliver good news, Mr. Trump consistently overpromises. Investors should learn to hold their celebrations.

title: 'The Revolutionary Genius of Plants' Review: Thinking Like a Flower
summary: It seems we have much to learn from our green companions-about everything from designing buildings to organizing society.. We humans take it for granted that plants are our inferiors. But they make earth habitable for us animals, by harnessing the energy of the sun to produce food and by releasing oxygen. That's not the only trick they have up their leaves. In this thought-provoking, handsomely illustrated book, Italian neurobiologist Stefano Mancuso considers the fundamental differences between plants and animals and challenges our assumptions about which is the "higher" form of life. It seems we have much to learn from our green companions-about everything from designing buildings to organizing society.

title: The Case for Buying Less Clothing
summary: For men with overstuffed closets, now's the ideal time to purge those impulse buys and pointless discount pants-and learn to shop smarter. IF ANY MAN reading this wants a down jacket, email me: I have four. I discovered this when I found a forgotten L.L. Bean puffer smushed in the nether regions of my closet. Why, you might ask, did I buy a jacket I didn't need? The eternal reason: because it was on sale. Last February, I'd wandered into an L.L. Bean in suburban Maryland to kill some time before dinner with zero intention to buy anything. Then I stumbled on a deal that felt too good to pass up and, just like that, I was down $75 and pointlessly up a down coat.

title: 'Unruly Waters' and 'Ganges' Review: In India, Water Is Politics
summary: While such a contention may be plausible for any part of the world, it is irrefutable in (south) Asia.. The opening shot of "Mother India," the most iconic film made in India in the decade after its independence, is of an old peasant woman struggling to grow crops on parched land. Behind her are rumbling tractors and earth movers, unsubtle symbols of progress. Then the camera pans past electric cables and newly metaled roads to a magnificent dam, which will bring water to the arid earth. The year is 1957, and this Bollywood dam, writes Sunil Amrith in "Unruly Waters," is a "vision of prosperity" in which "vulnerability to the weather is confined to the unhappy past." It is also the vision of a new India, "where technology and political freedom would triumph over nature."

title: 'In My Mind's Eye' Review: Marching Through the Days
summary: This is vintage Jan Morris-the mundane mingling with the majestic in a casual embrace.. British writer Jan Morris once said that she intended "Ciao, Carpaccio!," her 2014 work on an iconic Renaissance painter, to be the last book she'd publish.

title: 'The Paragon Hotel' Review: I'm Nobody! Who Are You?
summary: Blending film noir and screwball comedy, 'The Paragon Hotel' is about identity and family-those we're born into and those we create.. 'The Paragon Hotel" is set a century ago, but its themes of social and cultural upheaval feel sufficiently fresh that you might think twice about calling Lyndsay Faye's sixth novel historical fiction. But calling it terrific-not for a minute should you hesitate to do that.

title: 'Big Game' Review: Collision Course
summary: A raucous, smash-mouth, first-person takedown of the National Football League that is also the story of an aging fanboy who's too smart to ignore what's wrong with the game.. I was born to worship the pigskin. I got religion riding shotgun in my daddy's maroon-on-black fan-tailed Dodge sedan every Sunday afternoon listening to Al DeRogatis and Marty Glickman narrate the triumphs and travails of his New York Giants. He had been their water boy in 1927. His team remained precious to me until I started writing about all the ways football can break your heart-not to mention every other part of your body.

title: Charlotte Russe Reassesses Its Future, Including Sale or Bankruptcy
summary: Teen retailer hired Guggenheim Securities to explore strategic options, people familiar with the matter said. Charlotte Russe Inc., a mall-based fast-fashion retailer, is reassessing its future, including a possible sale or bankruptcy, less than a year after reaching a deal with its lenders to slash debt, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: 'Divided America' Myth Strokes Elite Egos
summary: Media elites position their class as the learned, dynamic, progressive wave of the future.. Elizabeth Currid-Halkett exposed "The False Stereotype of Two Americas" that has been peddled by the media since the 2016 election (op-ed, Dec. 27). That is, the myth of a U.S. divided between angry, less-educated, poor rural dwellers and smug, highly-educated urban and suburban elites. She showed that actual demographic differences are not nearly as stark as the divided-America spinners would have us believe.

title: The Pelosi Pay Raise
summary: There goes another argument against funding the wall.. Having already agreed to spend money on physical barriers to prevent illegal crossings of the U.S. southern border, Democrats are casting opposition to the particular architecture favored by President Donald Trump as a matter of conscience worth shutting down a portion of their beloved federal bureaucracy. This argument was already going to be difficult to sustain and Democrats have just made it even harder.

title: Versatile Greek Banker Helped Create Libor
summary: Minos Zombanakis was a pioneer in syndicated loans using funds stashed outside their country of origin.

title: Bank Stocks Rebound on Jobs Report, Powell Comments
summary: Shares in big lenders are sensitive to the economy as pace of borrowing ebbs and flows with growth. Battered bank stocks jumped on Friday after a strong jobs report and comments by the Federal Reserve chairman helped shift investors' narrative about economic growth.

title: U.S. Bond Prices Fall After Strong Labor Report, Supportive Powell Comments
summary: Employment gains and wage growth beat expectations. U.S. government bond prices fell Friday after strong Labor Department employment data and comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell emphasizing the central bank's willingness to be flexible in setting interest rates.

title: Heavy-Duty Truck Orders Tumbled 43% in December
summary: Analysts say a hefty backlog still will produce the strongest manufacturing year for big rigs in more than a decade. Orders for heavy-duty trucks in North America fell back to the lowest level in 17 months in December as a long surge in fleet expansion that has fueled big factory backlogs ran out of steam.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: Resume Subscription. The world rings in 2019, a new president takes office in Brazil, Nancy Pelosi reclaims the U.S. House speakership, and more from The Wall Street Journal's Photos of the Week: Dec. 28, 2018 to Jan. 4, 2019.

title: Best-Selling Books Week Ended Dec. 29
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: Former Top Fed Official Says Central Bank Should Better Convey Uncertainty
summary: Fed governors should also make higher-profile appearances, says Donald Kohn, Fed's former vice chairman. A former top Federal Reserve official is counseling current central bankers that monetary policy might work better if officials were able to convey how much uncertainty they have around the outlook.

title: Southwest Air CEO's Quirky Style Produced Reliable Profits
summary: Airline encouraged employees to joke around, kept strategy simple and avoided the most congested airports. Passengers new to Southwest Airlines , suddenly confronted by flight attendants warbling goofy songs or cracking jokes about in-flight safety, quickly realize they aren't flying with a typical airline.

title: Oil Rises on Jobs Report, Wall Street Rebound
summary: Optimism over economy fuels investor appetite for riskier assets. •Oil prices increased Friday for a fifth straight session amid rebounding stocks on Wall Street, a strong jobs report and hopes for a resolution to a U.S.-China trade fight. But a bearish report on weekly U.S. oil and fuel inventories turned oil investors cautious, reducing earlier gains.

title: Your Groceries Are in the Robot
summary: A look at some of the experiments in autonomous delivery vehicles. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: What Luxury Buyers Like
summary: Want to know what buyers want in a luxury home? Exhibit A: April and Anh-Tuan Truong's 1888 Greystone house in Chicago.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Tech Hiring Cools in December
summary: Employers across all industries in the U.S. shed 18,000 core information-technology jobs last month, a trade group reports. Employers across all industries in the U.S. shed 18,000 core information-technology jobs last month, amid broader employment gains for all occupations, CompTIA reports.

title: Republican Leader in New York State Senate Undergoing Rehab
summary: Sen. John Flanagan will miss start of legislative session for alcohol-dependency treatment. New York State Senate Republican Leader John Flanagan announced Friday that he would miss the opening of this year's legislative session as he undergoes treatment for alcohol dependency.

title: 'Victory City' Review: New World Capital
summary: During World War II, America went to war through the Port of New York. It was, in many ways, the making of the city.. New York is America's largest and most important city, but its role today gives little idea of the heights it reached in the middle of the last century.

title: Parcel Carriers Pulled Back Hiring in December
summary: Job additions earlier in the year and automation helped carriers get ahead of peak-season demand. Package-delivery firms pulled back on hiring at the height of peak shipping season, cutting payrolls by 5,200 jobs in December to end a 20-month expansion that has helped fuel strong employment growth in the transportation and logistics sector.

title: Double Whammy: High-Fee Mutual Funds Do Worse
summary: Fund managers who charge more than their peers often aren't worth the extra cost, an analysis suggests. For investors who pay a high fee to mutual-fund managers, the obvious question is: Are the fees worth it?

title: Fed's Mester Says There's Time to Decide What's Next for Rate Policy
summary: 'I think we are in a good spot,' says Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester. The leader of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, Loretta Mester, said Friday morning in a television interview just ahead of the December jobs release that the central bank has time before it has to decide what to do next with interest-rate increases.

title: Can You Pull Off a Beret if You're Not French?
summary: Sure, there's a 12% risk of looking silly in the au courant cap, but the rewards are considerable. A look into the cultural history of the definitive chapeau. BERETS REPRESENT three things I've always aspired to be: French, chic and confident. The first is a lost cause, given my Italian heritage and American upbringing. I'm working on the latter two. I've worn berets with varying degrees of success since childhood and sported a black iteration with a crystal-encrusted band to dine with my father just last month. He told me I looked "very French"-a high compliment coming from a man who proposed to his wife in the City of Lights.

title: Marijuana Is More Dangerous Than You Think
summary: As legalization spreads, more Americans are becoming heavy users of cannabis, despite its links to violence and mental illness. Over the past 30 years, a shrewd and expensive lobbying campaign has made Americans more tolerant of marijuana. In November 2018, Michigan became the 10th state to legalize recreational cannabis use; New Jersey and others may soon follow. Already, more than 200 million Americans live in states that have legalized marijuana for medical or recreational use. Yet even as marijuana use has become more socially acceptable, psychiatrists and epidemiologists have reached a consensus that it presents more serious risks than most people realize.

title: Vatican Bishop Under Investigation for Sex Abuse
summary: Bishop Gustavo Zanchetta, a compatriot of Pope Francis, is suspended from his financial post. VATICAN CITY-An Argentine bishop who holds a high Vatican post is under investigation for possible sex abuse, presenting a new challenge to Pope Francis as he struggles to respond to the Catholic Church's clerical-abuse crisis.

title: Fed's Barkin Sees Economy Slowing in 2019
summary: Richmond Fed leader doesn't comment on monetary policy.

title: The Family Secret Uncovered by a Writer's DNA Test
summary: Shocking results from a home genetic test shattered novelist Dani Shapiro's understanding of her identity. Throughout the 25 years of her writing life, Dani Shapiro, a prolific novelist and memoirist, has been obsessed with the themes of family and secrecy. Until recently, she says, "I couldn't have told you why."

title: Strong Jobs Report Puts Rate Increases Back in Play
summary: Analysts remain divided on the trajectory of monetary policy this year. Bond yields and stocks jumped in tandem as Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell spoke Friday, pointing to continued disagreement among investors about the likely course of monetary policy.

title: Buddhist Violence Portends New Threat to Myanmar
summary: Ethnic Rakhine Buddhists are fighting national military for autonomy in state that is still grappling with ethnic cleansing of Rohingya. A sharp escalation in fighting between a heavily armed Buddhist militia and Myanmar's military heralds a new threat to the conflict-ridden nation, just as it is seeing tentative progress in quelling other long-running ethnic and religious violence.

title: Roberts to Retire, Opening Race for Kansas Senate Seat
summary: Former governor, U.S. secretary of state are among the potential candidates. Sen. Pat Roberts, a Kansas Republican whose elected career has spanned nearly four decades across both Congressional chambers, will step down at the end of his term in 2020, he said Friday.

title: Massive Leak Strikes Germany's Political Class
summary: All of Germany's political parties are affected except the anti-immigrant Alternative for Germany. BERLIN-German authorities are investigating the leaking and hacking of personal data belonging to hundreds of politicians and other personalities in one of the country's largest cyber breaches.

title: Atlanta Fed's Bostic Defends Central Bank's Balance Sheet Wind Down
summary: Bostic says wind down is mechanical by design to avoid creating uncertainty. The mechanical shrinking of the Federal Reserve's balance sheet is designed to reduce uncertainty, but the path can change in response to unforeseen developments, said Raphael Bostic, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta.

title: $110 Million Malibu Mansion and the Biggest Luxury Buys of 2018
summary: The largest real-estate deals in the past 12 months include the $85 million sale of a billionaire heiress's Bel-Air pad and a Manhattan penthouse that sold for $73.8 million. In April 2018, natural-gas billionaire Michael S. Smith and his wife, Iris, bought a sprawling mansion on Malibu, Calif.'s Carbon Beach from Hard Rock Cafe founder Peter Morton for $110 million. The deal was the most expensive single-family residential sale in the country last year, based on an analysis of sales tracked by appraisal firm Miller Samuel for The Wall Street Journal. It also came close to the U.S. home-sale record, set in 2014 when hedge-fund manager Barry Rosenstein paid $137 million for a home in the Hamptons.

title: Is Red Wine Really the Cause of That Headache?
summary: Our wine columnist talked to experts in the fields of headache medicine and enology in search of strategies for avoiding the dreaded RWH (Red Wine Headache). I KNOW PLENTY of people who suffer from headaches that they believe are triggered by drinking red wine-including, occasionally, me. Red Wine Headache is such a common complaint that it has both an acronym (RWH) and its very own Wikipedia page, albeit with a disclaimer noting a lack of medical evidence regarding the condition and its causes. As Dr. Alexander Mauskop, director and founder of the New York Headache Center in Manhattan, said, "We don't know anything for sure."

title: Is Europe Ready to Defend Itself?
summary: As Donald Trump's America pulls back and Vladimir Putin's Russia looms, France and Germany are leading a renewed drive for a common European Union military.

title: A Reliquary Fit for a King-or Three
summary: The story of the Magi's visitation of the Christ Child caught hold of the popular imagination like few other biblical tales.. Of the Gospels' Nativity stories, Matthew's "mysterious 'wisemen' from the East caught popular Christian fancy earlier and more often that Luke's rather pedestrian shepherd-visitors from Bethlehem," observed Fr. Raymond Brown in his classic study, "The Birth of the Messiah." Indeed, the "wisemen" were rendered in Rome's Christian catacombs fully 200 years before the Nativity shepherds' first appearance in the fourth century.

title: Meet the Watchdog Called CryptoMom
summary: SEC's Hester Peirce-Republicans' muse on financial regulation-has won fans for her support of the digital-currency market. Cryptocurrency startups and traders fighting stricter regulation think they have their champion. They call her CryptoMom.

title: What 'Debunking' Owes to a 1923 Novel and Buncombe County, N.C.
summary: A flood of copyright expirations gives everyone new access to the fictional exploits of the original 'professional de-bunker,' but 'bunk' goes back even further. On January 1, works by thousands of writers and artists published in 1923 went into the public domain in the U.S. It marks the first time in two decades that such a large body of published material has lost its copyright status. Works from 1923 were supposed to go into the public domain back in 1999 after a 75-year term ran out, but before that could happen, Congress extended protection for another 20 years.

title: 'Pandemic 1918' and 'Influenza' Review: Fire, Ice or Virus?
summary: We know much more about influenza than did doctors during the great pandemic of 1918-19, when the cause of the illness was still unknown, but we also know that we have not mastered it.. Does 'flu' sound less serious than influenza? Do we often use a diminutive in an unconscious effort to tame collective fears of what, in their new books, Catharine Arnold dubs the "greatest medical holocaust in modern history" and Jeremy Brown calls "the deadliest disease in history"?

title: Bayer Shares Jump After Monsanto Weedkillers Ruling
summary: A U.S. judge granted a request from the German chemicals company to stagger the submission of evidence. BERLIN- Bayer AG shares rose by more than 6% Friday after the German chemicals company scored a court victory in the run-up to jury trials over whether Monsanto Co. weedkillers can cause cancer.

title: Ready, Set, Cheat: Electric Bikers Zoom Ahead of Mad Pedalers on Cycling App
summary: Amateur cyclists on the popular site Strava are in an uproar over alleged e-bike cheaters. Mountain biker Trevor Shepherd was feeling triumphant after reaching the top of a steep, rocky trail near his home in Manchester, England-posting a personal-best time of 3½ minutes.

title: Adoptions Powered by Algorithms
summary: A new online program designed by former eHarmony researchers generates 'compatibility scores' to try to better match prospective parents and children. There are almost a half million children in foster care in the U.S., and a quarter of them are waiting to be adopted. It is practically an article of faith in the world of child welfare that there is a shortage of families ready to help. But what if the shortage is not as severe as we think? What if we simply haven't done a good job pairing children with potential families?

title: Score From Jobs Report: Workers: 1, Companies: 0
summary: Fantastic jobs numbers signal great news for U.S. workers but not necessarily for U.S. companies. What if 2019 is a good year for U.S. workers but a bad one for U.S. companies?

title: Ultraluxury-Penthouse Sale Defies Slowing Manhattan Market
summary: A buyer is set to purchase a unit at 90 Morton St. that had been asking $40 million, likely making it one of downtown New York's most expensive transactions ever. A buyer has inked a deal to buy a penthouse apartment in Manhattan's West Village that was on the market for $40 million, according to listing agent Shlomi Reuveni of Reuveni Real Estate. If the deal closes at or near that price, it would be among the priciest residential sales below 14th Street in Manhattan, records show.

title: Daddy, What's a Sedan?
summary: U.S. auto sales show why manufacturers are killing off the vehicles in droves. While the vehicles that once dominated America's roads are a long way from extinction, plenty of storied sedans are headed for the scrap heap. Looking at Thursday's auto sales figures for 2018, it isn't hard to see why. Large or small, but especially large, the traditional vehicles are being killed off, mainly by U.S. manufacturers who are making all of their money from SUVs and light trucks these days. Of the top 25 selling vehicles in North America ranked by Car and Driver, the first sedan comes in at seventh place and the only American-made one at 23rd-the Ford Fusion, which is being discontinued.

title: Five Top Ideas About Aging from The Experts in 2018
summary: Whether the advice is to work a little longer or to start planning further ahead than we're used to, The Experts' most-popular posts on aging will help you manage these challenges in the new year.. In 2018, the WSJ Experts wrote about some of the ways people can age in better health and with more financial security than ever before.

title: Activision Blizzard Puts Financial Chief on Paid Leave, Intends to Fire Him
summary: Company said move is for unspecified cause, but for reasons unrelated to its financial reporting or disclosure procedures. Activision Blizzard Inc. put its chief financial officer on paid leave and intends to fire him, the company said in a securities filing Monday.

title: Ironwood Pharmaceuticals Picks AstraZeneca Executive to Be Next CEO
summary: Biotech firm reorganizing to focus on selling drugs for stomach diseases. An executive at British drugmaker AstraZeneca PLC has been tapped to lead Ironwood Pharmaceuticals Inc. after the biotech company reorganizes to focus on selling drugs for stomach diseases.

title: Today's Logistics Report: China Bites Apple; Cargo Lost at Sea; Leasing into Freighters
summary: Today's Top Supply Chain and Logistics News from WSJ. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: In a World Without Hard Cash, What's Left To Steal?
summary: Bills and pocket change are fading. 'A Fistful of Bitcoin,' anyone?.

title: Patrick Webb Helped Track Down Unabomber for FBI
summary: Seattle-born agent had a 34-year career and then landed a security job at Lucasfilm. As a teenager in Seattle in the early 1960s, Patrick Webb signed up for a Boy Scout program that allowed him to learn fingerprinting and ride with police officers in patrol cars. He was hooked.

title: Chinese Entrepreneur, Inspired by Forrest Gump, Circled Globe in a Single-Engine Plane
summary: Wei Chen moved to Memphis and thrived in the scaffolding business but yearned for a 'big hairy audacious goal'. Wei Chen was born in China amid the chaos of the Cultural Revolution. By his late 30s, he had established a thriving Memphis, Tenn.-based company distributing scaffolding and forklifts made in his homeland. He needed a bigger challenge.

title: Nancy Grace Roman Helped Win Funding for Hubble Telescope
summary: Scientist was NASA's first head of astronomy and won a rare accolade when Lego made her into a minifigure. Though she never won a Nobel Prize, the astronomer Nancy Grace Roman earned an accolade likely to give her even more cachet among tomorrow's scientists: In 2017, Lego AS released a Women of NASA set including a plastic likeness of Dr. Roman.

title: Illicit Guns Fuel 38% Murder Increase in Washington, D.C.
summary: The rise in homicides comes after years of improvements, and as nationwide murders trend lower. The number of homicides in Washington, D.C., soared 38% last year, a setback in the capital's safety record that defies the national trend of fewer murders.

title: How Magnetic Lashes Became the Biggest Thing in Beauty
summary: These newfangled false eyelashes-a real challenge to apply-were the top trending beauty search on Google in 2018. We quickly discovered why. IF YOU CONSIDER a quick swipe of mascara sufficient lash enhancement, this news may confound you, but among a growing segment of America's female population, false lashes are a daily staple. Touted by influencers like "Shahs of Sunset" star and Lilly Lashes founder Lilly Ghalichi, fake fringes are no longer fringe, with U.S. sales reaching nearly $270 million in 2018, up 31% from 2017, according to polling firm Nielsen. Fans of fake lashes value their exaggerated, eye-opening drama, but, with their messy, irritating glue, applying them has always been a pain.

title: A Smarter Way to Recover Hostages
summary: The U.S. strategy of refusing to negotiate with terrorist kidnappers endangers American lives for no good reason. Should governments ever pay ransom to terrorists who take hostages? The question divides experts and politicians. Spain and Italy have a reputation for being willing to pay whatever it takes to bring their citizens home, while the U.K. and the U.S. don't pay and in some cases don't even negotiate. As a result, many British and American hostages have been killed by their captors. In 2014, for instance, ISIS murdered its American and British hostages-including the journalists Jim Foley and Steven Sotloff-while cutting a deal for its European captives.

title: Despite Jobs Report, Fed Likely Won't Feel More Urgency to Raise Rates
summary: Central bank had penciled in two hikes before global outlook turned gloomier. The strong December employment report does little to clarify an economic outlook that is cloudier than it was when Federal Reserve officials voted last month to raise their benchmark interest rate.

title: Canada's Jobless Rate Holds Steady at 5.6%
summary: Job gain of 9,300 roughly matches expectations after surge in the previous month. OTTAWA-Canada's unemployment rate was unchanged in December as job creation came in close to market expectations following a surge in hiring during the previous month.

title: China Moves to Ramp Up Lending to Small Businesses
summary: Leadership moves to address weak link in economy as growth slows. BEIJING-China stepped up efforts to boost lending in its flagging economy, with the central bank freeing up new funds and the country's premier ordering big banks to lend to cash-starved small businesses.

title: Bigger Gifts Aren't Always Better
summary: A behavioral economist answers questions about gift-giving, organ donation and five-star hotels. Dear Dan,

title: Stocks to Watch: Square, Berkshire Hathaway, Apple, GM
summary: Resume Subscription. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Friday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: An Artist of Time and Space
summary: A new exhibition reveals Pierre Bonnard as more than a 'painter of happiness'. As the creator of vivid landscapes and sunlit domestic scenes, Pierre Bonnard (1867-1947) has long been known as a "painter of happiness." But as a new exhibition suggests, there is more to Bonnard than that cheerful sobriquet might imply. "Pierre Bonnard: The Colour of Memory," opening Jan. 23 at Tate Modern in London, reveals a restless, inventive artist whose explorations place him firmly within the currents of modern art and the history of his time.

title: Who's Who in the New Congress
summary: Democrat Pelosi leads a House with a record number of women; Republican-controlled Senate welcomes several new faces and shifts panel chiefs. The 116th session of Congress convened Thursday, with Democrats taking control of the House and Republicans expanding on their slim majority in the Senate.

title: U.K. Airports Bring Out the Big Guns to Stop Drones
summary: London Gatwick Airport says new equipment provides militarylike protection against drones. LONDON-British airports are boosting their counterdrone efforts after severe disruption during the holiday period, marking the first concrete sign that the three days of flight mayhem could be a catalyst for spending on systems to thwart the malicious use of unmanned aircraft.

title: How'd You Get That Job? Questions for a User Experience Researcher at Pinterest
summary: Larkin Brown, who studies how and why people use the social-media site, describes her role and how she got there in a new Wall Street Journal column that explores today's career paths.. Wondering what a "user experience researcher" does all day? Meet Larkin Brown, who works as one at Pinterest. She studies how and why people use Pinterest, a site where users search for products and ideas ranging from this afternoon's lunch to a maybe-someday dream house. In her role, Ms. Brown determines which features on the site need improving or what should be added to improve a consumer's visit.

title: Clemson Is the Only School That Actually Wants Alabama
summary: They're like an SEC team but with one huge benefit: They don't have to play the Crimson Tide until the College Football Playoff.. There are certain schools that are contractually obligated to submit themselves to college football's equivalent of a colonoscopy. They have to play Alabama.

title: The Most Important Quarterback in the NFL Playoffs: Brett Favre
summary: Resume Subscription. Andy Reid was combing through college football tape two years ago when he saw something that once astounded him three decades earlier and that he hadn't seen again since.

title: Mall Rent Growth Slowed Last Year, Poised to Slow Again in 2019
summary: Average rents in U.S. shopping malls gained less than 1% in the fourth quarter from a year earlier. Rental growth rates at U.S. malls and open-air shopping centers eased in the final quarter of 2018 and could slow further this year amid a difficult retail climate and signs of slower economic growth.

title: China Is a Problem for American Luxury, Too
summary: U.S. brands like Michael Kors and Coach are less dependent on China than European ones, but could be even more exposed in a luxury downturn. If China is buying fewer iPhones then there's a good chance it's buying fewer $1,000 handbags too. European brands are more directly in trouble, but may still weather the storm better than their U.S. rivals.

title: Apple Beware: Samsung's Great Fall in China Was Swift
summary: In five years, Samsung went from China's No. 1 to less than 1% market share. SEOUL- Apple Inc.'s recently revealed stumble in China is an all-too-familiar story for smartphone rival Samsung Electronics Co.

title: How to Avoid Flu: Six Feet, 48 Hours, 10 Days
summary: Here are some numbers to keep in mind as you try not to catch this year's bug. After a slow start, the flu season has taken off.

title: The Muscle Morgan Stanley Flexed in the $74 Billion Bristol-Myers Deal
summary: Joint venture with MUFG has given Morgan Stanley a $2.8 trillion balance sheet to compete with larger rivals. When Morgan Stanley sold one-fifth of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Inc. in 2008, naysayers said it had sold out too cheaply in the panic and shackled itself to a sleepy Japanese bank.

title: Apple: Time to Think Very Different
summary: IPhone maker may need to break with past practices and become more price-competitive to get out of its growth woes. Apple Inc.'s profit margins have long been the envy of the consumer-electronics world. Defending those margins may now be coming at a significant cost to what is no longer the world's most valuable company.

title: Winklevosses' Cryptocurrency Exchange: 'Revolution Needs Rules'
summary: New ad campaign also positions Gemini as a trustworthy harbor. Gemini Trust Co., the cryptocurrency exchange founded in 2014 by Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss, argues in a new ad campaign that its chaotic sector should protect investors by adopting standard best practices and following regulations. At the same time, not incidentally, the campaign suggests that Gemini already provides shelter from the storm.

title: House Passes Spending Package in Bid to End Shutdown
summary: On their first day in power, House Democrats rebuff President Trump on border-wall funding; Senate unlikely to take up House bills. WASHINGTON-House Democrats passed a spending package aimed at reopening the federal government, defying President Trump's demands for border-wall funding on their first day in power.

title: The China Story That Is Far Bigger Than Apple
summary: A tectonic shift in the country's economy has largely gone unnoticed by investors. China's economy is slowing so much it even tripped up Apple, while the clock ticks on the 90-day cease-fire in the U.S. trade feud. Less noticed amid the headlines is a major shift in the Chinese economy that is quietly beginning to upend the global financial system.

title: More First-Time Home Buyers Turn to Bank of Mom and Dad
summary: Among borrowers using FHA loans, which come with low down payments, more than 26% tap relatives for financial help. That's up from 22% in 2011.. Rising home prices are sending first-time buyers to their parents for help with mortgage down payments.

title: Cardinal's Trial to Draw Scrutiny of How Church Treats Abuse Cases
summary: Archbishop of Lyon is charged with failing to report a crime and endangering minors in wake of allegations that longtime priest abused dozens of children. PARIS-A trial of a French cardinal will spotlight how senior Catholic officials, including the Vatican's top watchdog, have handled decades-old accusations of child sexual abuse by priests.

title: GM, DoorDash to Test Autonomous Food Deliveries
summary: Restaurant-meal program expands push to build business models around self-driving technology. General Motors Co. 's self-driving car unit, Cruise, and DoorDash Inc. plan to provide food deliveries via autonomous vehicles, the latest attempt to use driverless technology to improve the shipment of goods.

title: Ghosn to Get First Public Hearing
summary: Lawyer for former Nissan chairman made the unusual demand that the court justify his detention. TOKYO-Carlos Ghosn is likely to get his first chance to make his case in public on Tuesday after his lawyer made the unusual demand that the Tokyo District Court justify his detention.

title: Apple Suppliers Slide in Asia as Investors Fret About Global Growth
summary: Resume Subscription. Apple Inc.'s surprisingly weak revenue outlook has dragged down shares of some of its Asian suppliers to multiyear lows, casting a shadow over global growth.

title: Japan's Corporate Revolution Deserves Another Look After Selloff
summary: Resume Subscription. Japan has struggled for decades to generate higher inflation: Now the country's stocks are looking nearly as cheap as its retail prices.

title: Two Strategic Days in Singapore: Where to Splurge, Where to Save
summary: No need to be crazy rich to live it up in the island-nation of Singapore. Here, two daylong itineraries-one for $1,684 a day, the other for $349 a day (including hotel stays). Regularly rated as southeast Asia's most expensive city, Singapore has a hefty supply of fine hotels and designer shopping enclaves as well as 39 Michelin-starred restaurants. Just slightly larger in area than Chicago, with twice the population, this city-state is a mecca for luxury lovers.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Have I Got a Fund For You! Why Brokers Push Some Investments
summary: Digging in to the fine print reveals the incentives that may lead investors to get conflicted advice. If only, in turbulent markets like these, you could know your financial adviser will always act in your best interest.

title: The $9 Billion Upcharge: How Insurers Kept Cash From Medicare
summary: CVS, UnitedHealth, Humana and other health insurers' bids to manage Part D prescription-drug plans for seniors have been consistently off in ways that benefit the companies at the expense of taxpayers. Each June, health insurers send the government detailed cost forecasts for providing prescription-drug benefits to more than 40 million people on Medicare.

title: Nancy Pelosi Wins Speaker Race
summary: First and only woman to hold the gavel leads Democratic chamber in era of divided government. WASHINGTON-Nancy Pelosi was elected House speaker as the 116th Congress convened Thursday and Democrats passed bills aimed at ending the partial government shutdown, but those measures were expected to stall in the GOP-controlled Senate.

title: Seasonal Work Visa Website to Reopen Monday
summary: The website shut down on January 1 after receiving nearly 100,000 requests for H-2B visas. WASHINGTON-A government portal for temporary worker visas is tentatively set to reopen Monday after crashing on New Year's Day because of overwhelming demand.

title: Hudson's Bay Chairman Buys Stake Held by Ontario Pension Fund
summary: Richard Baker and partners already have a controlling stake in the company. Richard Baker, who built Hudson's Bay Co. into a collection of famous department stores, is consolidating his hold on the company by buying a roughly 8% stake held by a large shareholder.

title: The Top 10 Upgrades to Sell Your Home for Top Dollar
summary: Resume Subscription. Want to know what it takes to sell a luxury home in a softening market? Ask Anh-Tuan and April Truong. In the fall, Dr. Truong, a cosmetic surgeon, and Ms. Truong, a stay-at-home mother to their two children, sold their 3,200-square-foot townhome in Chicago's Gold Coast neighborhood for $1.175 million after just 40 days on the market-while similar homes in the same condominium development languished for months.

title: 'Laughing Shall I Die' Review: The Minds of the Vikings
summary: A provocative image of the Vikings as raping-and-pillaging supermen endures in popular culture, but the reality is infinitely darker-and more intriguing.. A provocative image of the Vikings as raping-and-pillaging supermen endures in popular culture. Films, TV series and sports teams have appropriated the idea of Vikings as fierce, unyielding warriors and pirates of formidable stature. But the reality of Viking culture is infinitely more intriguing-and much darker than the fantasy.

title: Fiction: The Intimate Horrors of Human Nature
summary: An odd, piercing novel about students assigned to re-enact Iron Age life.. 'I can see her drowned / body in the bog, / the weighing stone, / the floating rods and boughs," Seamus Heaney wrote in his poem cycle inspired by the Iron Age corpses exhumed from the bogs of northern Europe. These bodies, eerily preserved by the peat, bear the marks of butchery and strangulation, telling ancient stories of corporal punishment or ritual sacrifice, and though the barbarity unsettles, Heaney knew that more disturbing still is the kinship felt among those of us "who would connive / in civilized outrage / yet understand the exact / and tribal, intimate revenge."

title: 'John O'Hara: Four Novels of the 1930s' Review: Big Fish in Small Towns
summary: John O'Hara's midcentury novels track with anthropological rigor the lives of middle-class Americans scrambling for status.. If a reader swore off every famous author who was an abrasive egomaniac, there would be precious few left to choose from; if you also eliminated the snobs, there would be none at all. John O'Hara set the bar very high in both categories. He made his name as a short-story writer at the New Yorker, which would publish more than 400 of his stories, far more than by any other writer in the magazine's history; then in 1949 he picked a quarrel with Harold Ross, the editor, because Ross didn't pay him a kill fee for rejected stories, an unheard-of expectation for fiction. The magazine lured O'Hara back 11 years later, only after agreeing to his capricious demand that they send an editor to his home in Quogue, Long Island, to read his manuscripts and make a decision on the spot whether to publish them. O'Hara long declared an ambition to win the Nobel Prize, which he planned to celebrate by buying a Rolls-Royce; after John Steinbeck won it, O'Hara concluded that he was out of the running and bought the Rolls as a consolation.

title: Southwest Airlines Co-Founder Herb Kelleher Dies
summary: Lawyer's strategy of low fares and frequent short hops forced other U.S. carriers to adapt. Herb Kelleher, the co-founder of Southwest Airlines Co. who died Thursday at the age of 87, followed a simple but groundbreaking strategy: Keep costs and fares low.

title: Children's Books: Tales Told in Many Tongues
summary: It takes all sorts to make a kingdom. We can't all be brave, wise and funny.. 'Our kingdom is filled with wise men and women. We have no fools," says an otherwise sensible king who has fallen under the flattering influence of a poet in "Mangoes, Mischief, and Tales of Friendship" (Candlewick, 179 pages, $16.99), a collection of eight stories from India by Chitra Soundar. Hearing the king make such an imprudent claim, his son Veera, and the prince's best friend, Suku, set out to demonstrate the opposite by identifying not one but five fools.

title: Five Best: James Holland on World War II Memoirs
summary: From the author, most recently, of 'Big Week: The Biggest Air Battle of World War II'. By Geoffrey Wellum (2002)

title: Cuomo Cancels Full L-Train Shutdown in New York City
summary: In surprise, governor reverses plan to close East River tube damaged by superstorm Sandy. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo swooped in Thursday to avert a looming shutdown of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's L train line between Brooklyn and Manhattan for 15 months that threatened to disrupt the commutes of hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers.

title: Apple's Troubles Extend Beyond China
summary: Confluence of events raises doubts about iPhone maker's business strategy. Apple Inc. chief Tim Cook blamed China's accelerating economic slowdown for stumbling iPhone sales that hurt its global revenue in the past quarter. The company's problems run deeper in China and extend to markets beyond.

title: Warhol-Themed Bar Hopes for More Than 15 Minutes of Fame
summary: The Factory 380 is latest New York City establishment centered around famous people or brands. Forget museum exhibitions. Andy Warhol now comes available as a cocktail, so to speak.

title: Advances in Cancer Drugs Fuel Bristol-Celgene Deal
summary: Resume Subscription. Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. 's blockbuster $74 billion deal to buy rival Celgene Corp. creates a cancer-drug powerhouse amid industrywide excitement about the rapidly evolving science and explosive growth of the sector.

title: Meal Subscription Service Freshly Hires Its New CMO From Spotify
summary: Mayur Gupta aims to help the startup stand out among 'food tech' players. Mayur Gupta, vice president of growth and marketing at Spotify Technology SA, is joining the prepared-meal subscription startup Freshly as chief marketing officer, effective Jan. 7. The post had been vacant since Sharon Fox left last spring.

title: Manchester City Is Back in the Premier League Race
summary: With Man City's victory over first-place Liverpool, the Premier League has its first truly competitive title race in four years. MANCHESTER, England-The end of Manchester City's title defense seemed so plausible before kickoff on Thursday night that everyone inside Etihad Stadium could sense it.

title: New L Train Plan Signals End of Williamsburg Rental Bargains
summary: Landlords and developers breathe sigh of relief following Gov. Andrew Cuomo's surprise announcement. The surprise decision to keep the L train running on weekdays during tunnel repairs is being cheered by Williamsburg landlords, who have lost significant revenue since the full shutdown plan was announced nearly three years ago.

title: New Jersey Employee Takes Step to Sue State Over Alleged Attacker
summary: The claim names Gov. Murphy, state Attorney General Grewal and seven others over hiring of her alleged assailant. A New Jersey employee who has criticized Democratic Gov. Phil Murphy's administration for not doing enough to respond to her sexual-assault allegation has taken an initial step to sue the state over its hiring of her accused attacker.

title: Ex-Bankers at Credit Suisse Arrested for Involvement in Mozambique Deals
summary: Former finance minister of Mozambique and an executive of Privinvest Group also face charges. Three former Credit Suisse Group AG bankers were arrested Thursday in London in connection with a $2 billion fraud scheme, according to a statement by the U.S. Department of Justice.

title: Intense Growth Fears Pummel Stocks After Apple Cuts Revenue Forecast
summary: Tim Cook's letter is latest sign to skittish investors that 'the slowdown is here and happening'. Fears about the health of the global economy intensified Thursday as downbeat news in the U.S. and around the world sent stocks falling and pushed bond yields to their lowest level in almost a year.

title: GameStop Struggles to Boost Sales
summary: With sales stagnating, retailer is looking for another CEO again and reviewing strategic alternatives. Videogame retailer GameStop Corp. is working to restructure its business as it searches for its fifth chief executive in a little over a year. But some say that to stay in the game, the retailer might be better off selling itself.

title: You Call That 'Infrastructure'?
summary: A bargain between Trump and Democrats may not be so easy.. As the new Congress is gaveled into session, the question is what a Democratic House and a Republican Senate can possibly accomplish. One common answer, or at least hope, is that perhaps America's builder-in-chief, President Trump, can push through a blockbuster infrastructure bill. Yet finding middle ground even here is going to prove difficult.

title: Shutdown Approaches the End of Its Second Week
summary: Trump makes first appearance before reporters in White House press-briefing room to make his case. WASHINGTON-President Trump made a surprise appearance Thursday at the White House press briefing room to insist on billions for a southern-border wall just hours before the new House Democratic majority planned to pass a bill that fell short of Mr. Trump's demands.

title: Rule Book from 1844 Becomes a Must-Read in Brexit Debate
summary: As Parliament struggles with how the U.K. should leave the European Union, an old rule book is being dusted off; 'a surprising and delightful revivification' of interest. LONDON-Paul Evans, a cardigan-clad clerk at Britain's Parliament, spent most of the past four decades diligently studying arcane rules and conventions in the shadows of Westminster Palace.

title: 'El Chapo' Jury Told of Cartel's Tricks, From Submarines to Laundry Carts
summary: Top lieutenant of Sinaloa drug cartel testifies against his former boss in Brooklyn federal court. The former logistics manager of the Sinaloa cartel testified at trial Thursday against his former boss Joaquín "El Chapo" Guzmán, giving jurors a rare opportunity to hear details of alleged high-level discussions within the cartel's inner circle.

title: Delta Cuts Revenue Forecast, Sparking Airline Selloff
summary: No. 2 airline said fare increases slowed during peak travel season. Delta Air Lines Inc. said fare revenue didn't climb as much as expected during the holiday travel season, fanning concerns that major carriers will struggle to maintain profits as lower fuel prices lead customers to expect cheaper flights.

title: Judge Blocks Airbnb Crackdown in New York City
summary: Court finds city law violated protections against illegal searches, in win for home-sharing companies. A federal judge blocked a New York City law intended to curb Airbnb Inc., giving a boost to the company and others that offer short-term rentals in the city.

title: Trump's Cracked Afghan History
summary: His falsehoods about allies and the Soviets reach a new low.. President Trump's remarks on Afghanistan at his Cabinet meeting Wednesday were a notable event. They will be criticized heavily, and deservedly so. The full text is available on the White House website.

title: The iPhone Canary
summary: Apple's sales plunge shows the need for a U.S.-China trade deal.. Investors have been searching for signs of how President Trump's trade standoff with China is affecting the U.S. economy. Judging by the market reaction to slumping iPhone sales in China, many fear Apple is the canary in the global economy. This may be an overreaction, but the Apple warning does underscore the interdependence of the U.S. and Chinese economies and their joint stake in a trade deal.
